==== Secondary literature ==== An unofficial anthology titled ''In the Hunt: Unauthorized Essays on Supernatural'' ({{ISBN|1933771631}}) was released on February 10, 2009, by Smart Pop and featured essays covering different aspects of both the series and its fanbase. ''The Mythology of Supernatural: The Signs and Symbols Behind the Popular TV Show'' ({{ISBN|0425241378}}), published by Berkley Trade on August 2, 2011, sought to explore the religious and mythological roots of the show. And on October 1, 2011, ECW Press released the book ''TV Goes to Hell: An Unofficial Road Map of Supernatural'' ({{ISBN|1770410201}}) which explored topics such as folklore, religion, gender and sexuality, comedy, and music through essays from a number of contributors.
=== Spin-off series ===
==== ''Ghostfacers'' ==== The growing popularity of "amateur spook-hunters" Ed Zeddmore and Harry Spangler prompted Kripke to consider a spin-off series for the characters. He discussed the idea of an online venture with actors [[A. J. Buckley]] and [[Travis Wester]], and held a successful meeting with studio and network executives.<ref name="ghostfacersm">{{cite news |url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2010/04/supernatural-ghostfacers.html |work=Chicago Tribune |first=Maureen |last=Ryan |date=April 15, 2010 |title='Supernatural's' Ghostfacers scare up their own Web series}}</ref> Though Kripke announced their plans to produce "some new material, either webisodes, potentially cell phone content or basically an off-network ''Ghostfacers'' series" at the 2008 [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]],<ref name="ghostfacersk" /> the economic downturn delayed production until 2009.<ref name="ghostfacersm" />
Buckley and Wester, along with Patrick J. Doody and Chris Valenziano, penned the series.<ref name="ghostfacersm" /> They found the format—ten three-minute segments<ref name="ghostfacersv" />—difficult to manage because each webisode has to work both individually and as part of the overall storyline.<ref name="ghostfacersm" /> However, Wester noted, "We couldn't get too indulgent, we couldn't delve into long conversations. That helps not only with the storytelling but with the comedy... With drama, it takes time to establish an emotional connection with the characters. With comedy, you can jump right in."<ref name="ghostfacersm" />
Though an initial idea of Kripke's involved the cast searching real haunted houses,<ref name="ghostfacersk">{{cite web |url=http://www.eonline.com/news/20712/supernatural-boys-dish-on-new-season-possible-spinoff |title=Supernatural Boys Dish on New Season, Possible Spinoff |publisher=E! |first=Kristin |last=Dos Santos |date=July 28, 2012 |accessdate=July 29, 2012}}</ref> the first season instead features the Ghostfacers investigating a haunted theater. The series also stars [[Brittany Ishibashi]] as Maggie and [[Austin Basis]] as Spruce.<ref name="ghostfacersv">{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2010/digital/news/supernatural-spawns-web-spinoff-1118014263/ |work=Variety |title='Supernatural' spawns Web spinoff |first=Michael |last=Schneider |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=January 11, 2015}}</ref>
In August 2011, a webisode was released online in which the Ghostfacers meet Castiel.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://screenrant.com/supernatural-ghostfacers-castiel/ |title=Unreleased 'Supernatural' Ghostfacers Webisode With Castiel Revealed [Updated] |publisher=Screen Rant |first=Michael |last=Crider |date=August 3, 2011 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref>
==== ''Supernatural: The Anime Series'' ==== On June 9, 2010, the official Japanese Warner Bros. website announced an anime version of the series titled ''Supernatural: The Animation'' (スーパーナチュラル・ザ・アニメーション), which debuted in Japan in January 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-06-09/supernatural-the-animation-project-launched-in-japan |title=Supernatural The Animation Project Launched in Japan |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 10, 2010}}</ref> and is produced by Japanese anime studio [[Madhouse (company)|Madhouse]].<ref name="animenn">{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-06-10/madhouse-makes-anime-for-warners-supernatural-tv-show |title=Madhouse Makes Anime For Warners Supernatural TV Show |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=June 10, 2010}}</ref> Shigeyuki Miya and [[Atsuko Ishizuka]] are co-directors for the series, with Kripke credited as the project creator.<ref name="animenn" /> Madhouse co-founder [[Masao Maruyama (film producer)|Masao Maruyama]] serves as executive producer, with Naoya Takayama supervising the scripts and Takahiro Yoshimatsu designing the characters. [[Yūya Uchida (voice actor)|Yūya Uchida]] and [[Hiroki Touchi]], who voice Sam and Dean for the Japanese dub of the live-action series, reprise their roles.<ref name="animenn" />
The anime's first season consists of 22 half-hour episodes; while the storyline covers the first two seasons of the live-action series, it also includes original content exploring the Winchesters' childhoods and expanding upon secondary characters.<ref name="animenn" /> [[Warner Home Video]] released the first two episodes on Blu-ray and DVD in Japan on January 12, 2011; episodes 3 through 12 shipped on February 2, and the rest on April 6.<ref name="animenn" /> Warner Home Video released the Blu-ray and DVD box sets of the anime series on July 26, 2011, in North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-04-04/supernatural-the-anime-ships-in-north-america-in-july |title=Supernatural the Anime Ships in North America in July |publisher=Anime News Network |date=April 4, 2011}}</ref>
Jared Padalecki voices Sam in the English-language version of the series, while Jensen Ackles voices Dean only in the last two episodes for scheduling reasons; Andrew Farrar voices Dean in English for the first 20 episodes.
==== ''Supernatural: Bloodlines'' ==== {{Main|Supernatural: Bloodlines}} On July 22, 2013, The CW announced there was a spin-off of ''Supernatural'' in the works, with the 20th episode of season nine serving as a back-door pilot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/07/22/supernatural-spin-off-in-development-at-the-cw/193165/ |title='Supernatural' spin-off in the works at The CW |last=Bibel |first=Sara |work=TV by the Numbers |date=July 22, 2013 |accessdate=July 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122210651/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/07/22/supernatural-spin-off-in-development-at-the-cw/193165/ |archivedate=January 22, 2014}}</ref> On January 29, 2014, it was revealed that the spin-off was to have been titled ''Supernatural: Bloodlines''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2014/01/29/supernatural-tribes-spinoff-the-cw-cast/ |title=Pilot Scoop: CW Orders Rob Thomas’ iZombie – Plus, Supernatural Spin-Off Gets a Title |last=Ausiello |first=Michael |publisher=TVLine |date=January 29, 2014 |accessdate=January 29, 2014}}</ref>
The backdoor pilot was written by Andrew Dabb and directed by Robert Singer. The series was going to set to explore the "clashing hunter and monster cultures in Chicago". The show was not picked up by the CW for the 2014–2015 season. However, the network has remained open to another spin-off of the series.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2014/05/08/the-cw-new-series-fall-2014-the-flash/ |title=Fall TV Scoop: The CW Orders Four Dramas, Including Flash, iZombie and Jane the Virgin, Passes on Supernatural Spin-Off |publisher=TVLine |first=Michael |last=Ausiello |date=May 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thewrap.com/cw-passes-supernatural-spinoff-bloodlines |title=CW Passes on 'Supernatural' Spinoff 'Bloodlines' |last=Molloy |first=Tim |publisher=[[TheWrap]] |date=May 8, 2014 |accessdate=May 8, 2014}}</ref>
==== Samuel Colt ==== During production of ''Supernatural''{{'}}s third season, Kripke stated that the writers sometimes discussed the possibility of a prequel series. Set in the [[American Old West|Old West]], the spin-off would follow [[Samuel Colt]] and a group of hunters.<ref name="lastname" />
==== ''Wayward Sisters'' ==== On June 20, 2017, it was announced that ''Wayward Sisters'', a spin-off series starring [[Kim Rhodes]] as Sheriff [[Jody Mills]], was being developed by ''Supernatural'' writer-producers Andrew Dabb and Robert Berens, along with Robert Singer and Phil Sgriccia. The spin-off debuted as a [[backdoor pilot]] during the [[Supernatural (season 13)|thirteenth season]] of ''Supernatural''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/supernatural-spinoff-wayward-sisters-kim-rhodes-the-cw-backdoor-pilot-season-13-1202116253/ |title='Supernatural' Spinoff 'Wayward Sisters' Starring Kim Rhodes Set As Backdoor Pilot For Season 13 Of CW Series |work=Deadline Hollywood |date=June 20, 2017 |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |accessdate=June 21, 2017}}</ref> In May 2018, it was confirmed that the series was not picked up.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2018/05/11/supernatural-spinoff-wayward-sisters-cancelled-the-cw/ |title=Supernatural Spinoff Wayward Sisters Not Going to Series at The CW |work=TVLine |date=May 11, 2018 |first=Vlada |last=Gelman |accessdate=May 12, 2018}}</ref>
== Impact ==

After the first four episodes of ''Supernatural'' aired in 2005, the WB decided to pick up the series for a full season of 22 episodes. During those first episodes, the series was ranked third in males aged 18–34 and 12–34. It also posted an increase of 73% in males aged 18–49 from the year before, although it only gained 4% in total viewers, and retained 91% of viewers from its lead-in, ''[[Gilmore Girls]]''.<ref>{{cite press |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2005/10/06/supernatural-given-full-season-pick-up-by-the-wb-19444/20051006wb01/ |title=Supernatural Given Full-Season Pick-Up by the Wb |date=October 6, 2005 |publisher=The WB |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> ''Supernatural'' had low ratings during its second season, with viewers consisting mainly of teen girls, and the CW trying to attract more male viewers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/tv/2007/03/15/TV-Preview-Supernatural-tries-to-come-out-of-the-shadows/stories/200703150354 |title=TV Preview: 'Supernatural' tries to come out of the shadows |last=Owen |first=Rob |date=March 15, 2007 |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> The show's future was in doubt at the end of the second season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/tv/11918311.html |title=Supernatural ratings less than super |last=McFarland |first=Melanie |date=November 23, 2007 |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |accessdate=September 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308165151/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/tv/11918311.html |archivedate=March 8, 2008}}</ref> Despite mediocre ratings in the previous year, it was back for a third season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medialifemagazine.com/this-time-the-cw-network-gets-it-right/ |title=This time, the CW network gets it right |last=Downey |first=Kevin |date=September 28, 2007 |work=Media Life Magazine |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> Although its third season's rating were low, it did well with viewers aged 18–49. In this category, it ranked eighth of all returning series broadcast by a major network.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/18/AR2008091803997_pf.html |title=So, America's Going Steady With 'Survivor' |last=de Moraes |first=Lisa |date=September 19, 2008 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> The show received an early pickup for its fourth season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eonline.com/news/57639/cw-wants-more-model-gossip-chris |title=CW Wants More Model, Gossip, Chris |last=Serpe |first=Gina |date=March 3, 2009 |publisher=E! |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> The show's ratings increased in its fourth season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=117537 |title='Supernatural' actor Misha Collins is the new angel on the block |last=Spelling |first=Ian |date=December 14, 2008 |publisher=ReadingEagle.com |accessdate=September 14, 2009}}</ref> The fourth-season premiere aired on September 18, 2008, averaging its highest rating ever since its debut on [[The CW]] with 3.96 million viewers, a 33% surge over the season three premiere and a 1.7/5 in adults 18–49, up 42% from one year earlier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2008/09/19/thursday-september-18-flashpoint-nightmares-and-supernatural-score/5193/ |title=Thursday, September 18: Flashpoint Shines for CBS, Supernatural's Strong Debut |first=Bill |last=Gorman |date=September 19, 2008 |accessdate=September 19, 2008 |work=TV by the Numbers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019203834/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2008/09/19/thursday-september-18-flashpoint-nightmares-and-supernatural-score/5193/ |archivedate=October 19, 2012}}</ref> On October 16, 2008, the show was watched by 3.06 million viewers, making the lowest rating for the season. On October 30, 2008, the show climbed to its best performance in adults 18–34 (1.4/4), adults 18–49 (1.5/4) and total viewers (3.6mil) since its season premiere on September 18, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2008/10/31/smallville-and-supernatural-on-the-rise/7337/ |title="Smallville" and "Supernatural" on the Rise... |date=October 31, 2008 |work=TV by the Numbers |first=Robert |last=Seidman |accessdate=September 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131163819/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2008/10/31/smallville-and-supernatural-on-the-rise/7337 |archivedate=January 31, 2011}}</ref> For the fifth-season premiere, viewership increased by 6% in women 18–34 (1.7/5) over the fourth-season premiere.<ref>{{cite press |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2009/09/11/chicks-dig-the-vampires-vampire-diaries-sets-record-as-the-cws-most-watched-series-premiere-ever-32663/20090911cw01/ |title=Chicks Dig the Vampires! Vampire Diaries Sets Record as the CW's Most Watched Series Premiere Ever |date=September 11, 2009 |publisher=The CW |accessdate=September 20, 2009}}</ref> However, taking DVR viewings into account with new Live-Plus 7 Day data, total viewership for the premiere increased 38%, with women 18–34 increasing by 35% and adults 18–34 by 47%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2009/10/01/dvr-spells-omg-ratings-for-cw-32899/20091001cw01/ |title=DVR Spells OMG Ratings for CW |date=October 1, 2009 |publisher=The CW |accessdate=September 20, 2009}}</ref>
=== Awards and nominations === {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Supernatural}}
=== Reception === Early reception to the series was generally mixed, but has grown more favorable reviews from critics as it progressed.
The first season received a Metacritic score of 59 out of 100 based on 22 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/supernatural/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Supernatural Season 1 |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref> The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported a 69% approval rating for the first season, with an average rating of 6.8/10 based on 13 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "Despite some too-hip dialogue and familiar thematic elements, ''Supernatural'''s vigilante brothers manage to stir up some legitimate scares."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s01/ |title=Supernatural: Season 1 (2005–2006) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref> Subsequent seasons have also enjoyed positive reviews on the site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s02/ |title=Supernatural: Season 2 (2006–2007) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s04/ |title=Supernatural: Season 4 (2008–2009) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s05/ |title=Supernatural: Season 5 (2009–2010) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s06/ |title=Supernatural: Season 6 (2010–2011) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s07/ |title=Supernatural: Season 7 (2011–2012) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s08/ |title=Supernatural: Season 8 (2012–2013) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s09/ |title=Supernatural: Season 9 (2013–2014) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/supernatural/s10/ |title=Supernatural: Season 10 (2014–2015) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=February 17, 2015}}</ref> Tanner Stransky of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the first season a B, saying the show "comes off as weekly installments of a horror movie series", but that "Adding to the show's cred are the '67 Chevy Impala the boys rumble around in and their kick-ass soundtrack".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1531991,00.html |title=Supernatural: The Complete First Season (2006) |last=Stransky |first=Tanner |date=September 6, 2006 |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=September 24, 2009}}</ref> Jeff Swindoll of ''[[Monsters and Critics]]'' "really liked" the first season<ref name="mac2" /> for its "horrific content and the brotherly chemistry between its two stars". He also noted that the season finished "with one bang of a cliffhanger".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1198720.php |title=DVD Review: Supernatural – The Complete First Season |last=Swindoll |first=Jeff |date=September 6, 2006 |publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008003414/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1198720.php |archivedate=October 8, 2010}}</ref> Swindoll enjoyed the second season, too, saying that it "still works thanks to the brotherly chemistry between Padalecki and Ackles" and noted the second season focused more on the show's mythology.<ref name="mac2">{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1354007.php/DVD_Review_Supernatural_-_The_Complete_Second_Season |title=DVD Review: Supernatural – The Complete Second Season |last=Swindoll |first=Jeff |date=September 10, 2007 |publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002142629/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1354007.php/DVD_Review_Supernatural_-_The_Complete_Second_Season |archivedate=October 2, 2012}}</ref>
Swindoll also liked the third season, saying "Eric Kripke must've sold his soul to the devil so that the show wouldn't suffer a third season slump." He also enjoyed the moments featuring Bobby Singer ([[Jim Beaver]]), likening him to the character Cooter from ''[[Dukes of Hazzard]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1429895.php/Supernatural_-_The_Complete_Third_Season_%E2%80%93_DVD_Review |title=Supernatural: The Complete Third Season – DVD Review |last=Swindoll |first=Jeff |date=September 10, 2008 |publisher=Monsters and Critics |accessdate=September 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625024646/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1429895.php/Supernatural_-_The_Complete_Third_Season_%E2%80%93_DVD_Review |archivedate=June 25, 2013}}</ref> However, Daniel Bettridge of ''Den of Geek'' believed that the writer's strike hindered the season, with many issues being left unresolved and the finale feeling "a little rushed". He also felt that new characters Ruby ([[Katie Cassidy]]) and Bela ([[Lauren Cohan]]) were "disappointingly unexplored and ineffectively used".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.denofgeek.com/dvd-bluray/7735/supernatural-season-3-dvd-review |title=Supernatural season 3 DVD review |publisher=Den of Geek |first=Daniel |last=Bettridge |date=August 26, 2008 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> While Diana Steenbergen of IGN liked that there was a season-long story arc with Dean's demonic deal, she believed that viewers would know that the pact would not be resolved until the finale, making the self-enclosed episodes feel like they are "treading water, waiting for the main storyline to resume".<ref>{{cite web |last=Steenbergen |first=Diana |url=http://ign.com/articles/2008/05/24/supernatural-season-3-review |title=Supernatural: Season 3 Review |publisher=IGN |date=May 23, 2008 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> In 2008, [[AOL TV]] placed the show on its list of TV's Biggest Guilty Pleasures.<ref>{{cite web |title=TV's Biggest Guilty Pleasures |url=http://www.aoltv.com/2008/01/02/biggest-best-tv-guilty-pleasures/ |publisher=AOL TV |accessdate=September 16, 2012 |date=January 2, 2008}}</ref>
Another ''Monsters and Critics'' reviewer, June L., gave the fourth season a positive review, saying the show "remains intriguing and entertaining, giving viewers much to ponder in terms of the philosophical analysis of the nature of good and evil."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1498683.php/Supernatural-The-Complete-Fourth-Season-%E2%80%93-DVD-Review |title=Supernatural: The Complete Fourth Season – DVD Review |last=L. |first=June |date=September 2, 2009 |publisher=Monsters and Critics |accessdate=September 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108022307/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/dvd/reviews/article_1498683.php/Supernatural-The-Complete-Fourth-Season-%E2%80%93-DVD-Review |archivedate=January 8, 2010}}</ref> Steenbergen felt that the series made a transition from a "pretty good show to being a pretty great show". She praised Misha Collins for his portrayal of the angel Castiel, and felt that the interactions between Dean and Castiel were "one of the highlights of the season".<ref>{{cite web |last=Steenbergen |first=Diana |url=http://ign.com/articles/2009/05/22/supernatural-season-4-review |title=Supernatural: Season 4 Review |publisher=IGN |date=May 22, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> Before the premiere of the fifth season, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' listed the series as one of "The 50 Best Reasons to Watch TV", citing Sam and Dean Winchester as the "Bo and Luke Duke of demon hunting".<ref>{{cite journal |work=Rolling Stone |title=The 50 Best Reasons to Watch TV |date=September 2009}}</ref>
The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'''s Maureen Ryan named ''Supernatural'' among the top ten shows of 2009, stating that the "thoughtfully crafted show got bolder and more creative in 2009, coming up with hilarious and innovative episodes and taking risks with its storytelling."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2009/12/sons-of-anarchy-modern-family-big-bang-theory-supernatural-chuck-dollhouse.html |title=Watch this: The Top TV shows of 2009 |last=Ryan |first=Maureen |date=December 14, 2009 |work=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=December 14, 2009}}</ref> Mike Hale of ''[[The New York Times]]'' also named the series on his top ten list for the year: "''Supernatural'' is currently among the wildest and most entertaining series in prime time."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/20/arts/television/20hale.html |title=A Top 10 List That Needs an Addendum |last=Hale |first=Mike |date=December 18, 2009 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=December 18, 2009}}</ref> In 2010, AOL TV ranked ''Supernatural'' fourth of the Top 20 Magic/Supernatural Shows of All Time, noting that the show had been compared to ''[[The X-Files]]'' early in its run before "distinguishing itself as a unique, unpredictable and addictive series that not only features monsters, magic and Lucifer himself, but also boasts a dynamic duo arguably better at the banter than [[Fox Mulder|Mulder]] and [[Dana Scully|Scully]] -- Sam and Dean Winchester".<ref name="top20">{{cite web |title=Top 20 Magic/Supernatural Shows of All Time |url=http://www.aoltv.com/best-shows-ever/magic-supernatural-shows/ |publisher=AOL TV |accessdate=March 7, 2015 |date=December 9, 2010}}</ref>
In 2012, ''Entertainment Weekly'' listed the show at No. 19 in the "25 Best Cult TV Shows from the Past 25 Years", saying, "''Supernatural'' began with a pretty straightforward premise – hot guys kill spooky things – but it didn't stay that way for long. The characters have literally been to [[hell]] and back, and along the way, they have woven a complicated and compelling mythology filled with friends (angel Castiel), recurring foes (demon Crowley), and inside jokes (Wincest!). ''Supernatural'' has also, however, dedicated episodes to mocking the sillier aspects of its own existence, like its hypercritical fandom. This self-referential approach has rewarded longtime viewers and helped build a community so passionate, it's almost scary."<ref>"25 Best Cult TV Shows from the Past 25 Years", ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. August 3, 2012, p. 42.</ref> The show has a broad demographic base and is more popular in Russia than the US.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rodriguez |first1=Ashley |title=TV's new longest-running fantasy show unites Democrats and Republicans—and Russians |url=https://qz.com/1100849/supernatural-the-tv-show-that-unites-democrats-and-republicans-and-russians/ |accessdate=October 12, 2017 |work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |date=October 12, 2017}}</ref>
=== Syndication === On January 4, 2010, the cable television network [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]] began airing reruns of ''Supernatural''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2009/12/13/exclusive-tnt-lands-supernatural-repeats-33819/8423/ |title=Exclusive: TNT Lands "Supernatural" Repeats |publisher=The Futon Critic |first=Brian Ford |last=Sullivan |date=December 13, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> In Canada, the series has been syndicated on [[Space (Canadian TV channel)|Space]], [[Dusk (TV channel)|Dusk]], [[ABC Spark]], [[M3 (Canadian TV channel)|M3]], and [[E! (Canadian TV channel)|E!]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.ca/Supernatural.aspx |title=Supernatural |publisher=Space |accessdate=November 23, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125111355/http://www.space.ca/Supernatural.aspx |archivedate=November 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://shaw.ca/uploadedFiles/Customer_Bulletins/DUSK_Shutdown_FAQs-Shaw.pdf |title=DUSK Shutdown FAQs |publisher=Shaw |accessdate=November 23, 2014 |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.m3tv.ca/shows/supernatural |title=Supernatural |publisher=M3 |accessdate=November 23, 2014}}</ref>
=== Fandom and popular culture === <!-- ANY UNSOURCED ADDITIONS REGARDING DESTIEL AND WINCEST WILL BE REMOVED --> Being a [[Cult following|cult]] series, ''Supernatural'' has garnered a dedicated fanbase.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20270843_3,00.html |title='Supernatural': Sexy. Scary. Over? |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> They are active online,<ref>{{cite web |last=Goldman |first=Eric |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/04/17/supernatural-behind-the-scenes-and-behind-the-demons?page=2 |title=Supernatural: Behind the Scenes and Behind the Demons |publisher=IGN |date=April 17, 2007 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> and many have written [[fanfiction]] stories about the show, ranging from Wincest (the romantic pairing of brothers Dean and Sam Winchester) to Destiel (the romantic pairing of Dean Winchester and Castiel) to various other character pairings. The writers have referenced this several times in the series,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/supernatural-slash-this-is-wro-31170.aspx |title='Supernatural' Slash: "This is Wrong" |publisher=BuddyTV |first=John |last=Kubicek |date=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> including the 200th episode, which makes references to Wincest, Destiel, and Sastiel (the romantic pairing of Sam Winchester and Castiel).<ref>{{cite web |last=Sastry |first=Keertana |url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/48816-supernatural-addresses-wincest-destiel-the-lack-of-female-characters-more-in-its-200th-episode |title='Supernatural' Addresses Wincest, Destiel, the Lack of Female Characters, & More in Its 200th Episode |publisher=Bustle |date=November 11, 2014 |accessdate=January 4, 2015}}</ref>
The first fan conventions dedicated to ''Supernatural'' took place in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in October 2006<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://journal.transformativeworks.org/index.php/twc/article/viewArticle/208/151 |title=Interview with Wincon organizer Ethrosdemon |editor=TWC Editor |journal=Transformative Works and Cultures |volume=4 |year=2010 |doi=10.3983/twc.v4i0.208 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724230313/http://journal.transformativeworks.org/index.php/twc/article/viewArticle/208/151 |archivedate=July 24, 2011 |df=mdy-all}}</ref> and in [[London]] in May 2007,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/jensen-ackles-headed-to-firste-6330.aspx |title=Jensen Ackles Headed To First-ever Supernatural Convention |publisher=BuddyTV |first=Kris |last=De Leon |date=May 10, 2007 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> and conventions have since expanded through to Germany and throughout the United States. The series' stars and large guest cast make appearances,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/supernatural-stars-to-attend-c-10199.aspx |title='Supernatural' Stars to Attend Convention Saluting Various Genre Series |publisher=BuddyTV |first=Lisa |last=Claustro |date=September 2, 2007 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> with fans from the United States, Europe, China, and Australia attending.<ref name="eclipsemagazine" />
Before the debut of the series' [[Supernatural (season 5)|fifth season]], in which [[Lucifer (Supernatural)|Lucifer]] is finally freed from his imprisonment, fans attempted to promote the show through [[Twitter]]. Enough fans posted the [[Tag (metadata)#Hash tags|hash tag]] "#LuciferIsComing" that it made it into "[[trending topic]]s"<ref name="twitter1" /><ref name="twitter2" /> – a list depicting words and phrases posted with the highest frequency on the website.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blog.twitter.com/2009/twitter-search-everyone |title=Twitter Search for Everyone! |publisher=Twitter |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> However, Twitter users who were unaware of the fans' intentions responded with numerous posts of "#GodIsHere", and the topic was blocked from Twitter's trending topics after complaints. Actor [[Misha Collins]], who portrays [[Castiel (Supernatural)|Castiel]] in the series, tried to continue the campaign by requesting that fans post "#PDiddyIsScaredOfHisTV", rapper [[P. Diddy]] being the one whom many fans believe to be the instigator of the initial backlash.<ref name="twitter1">{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/lucifer-is-coming-how-supernat-31138.aspx |title=Lucifer is Coming: How 'Supernatural' Stole Twitter |publisher=BuddyTV |first=John |last=Kubicek |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref name="twitter2">{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/misha-collins-supernatural-fan-31194.aspx?pollid=600001057&answer=600003597 |title=Misha Collins and 'Supernatural' Fans Declare Twitter War on P. Diddy |publisher=BuddyTV |first=John |last=Kubicek |date=September 14, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> However, after an hour, this attempt to trend the topic was also stymied by Twitter.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/supernatural/is-twitter-silencing-supernatu-31275.aspx |title=Is Twitter Silencing 'Supernatural' Fans Again? |publisher=BuddyTV |first=John |last=Kubicek |date=September 17, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref>
In honor of the series' season 14 renewal, [[Mayor of Austin|Mayor]] [[Steve Adler (lawyer)|Steve Adler]] of [[Austin, Texas]] declared June 23, 2018 as "''Supernatural'' Day" in the city, as the show's stars Ackles and Padalecki are both Austin residents. The day, which coincided with the duo participating in local charity events, also recognized ''Supernatural'' for, as the declaration proclaimed, "bringing the best fans in the world" to the city.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbr.com/supernatural-day-austin-texas/ |title=Supernatural Day Proclaimed by Austin, Texas Mayor |website=[[Comic Book Resources]] |last=Gumeny |first=Eirik |date=June 27, 2018 |accessdate=June 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://comicbook.com/tv-shows/2018/06/27/supernatural-day-declared-by-austin-texas-mayor/ |title='Supernatural' Day Declared by Austin, Texas Mayor |website=''ComicBook.com'' |last=Burlingame |first=Russ |date=June 26, 2018 |accessdate=June 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://screenrant.com/supernatural-holiday-austin-texas/ |title=Supernatural Gets Its Own Holiday in Austin, Texas |website=Screen Rant |last=Elvy |first=Craig |date=June 26, 2018 |accessdate=June 29, 2018}}</ref>

The '''Tanacu exorcism''' was a case in which Maricica Irina Cornici, a mentally ill nun at the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]] monastery of [[Tanacu]] in [[Vaslui County]], [[Romania]], was killed during an [[Exorcism in Christianity|exorcism]] led by priest Daniel Petre Corogeanu and four Orthodox Christian nuns who were a part of the Order of the Holy Trinity.<ref name="Connolly2005">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/romania/1492445/Possessed-nun-crucified-after-row-with-priest.html|title='Possessed' nun crucified after row with priest|last=Connolly|first=Kate|date=20 June 2005|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref> The case was widely publicized in the Romanian media and, following a lengthy trial, the priest was sentenced on appeal to 7 years, one nun to 6 years and the other three nuns to 5 years. They were all found guilty of deprivation of liberty resulting in the victim's death. They received a relatively lenient sentence, compared to the original desire of the [[prosecution]] who sought [[life imprisonment]] for the priest. Many of Tanacu's residents, including Cornici's brother, believed her to have suffered from [[demonic possession]].<ref name="casualty"/><ref name="FN2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/02/19/romanian-priest-gets-14-years-for-killing-nun-in-exorcism.html|title=Romanian Priest Gets 14 Years for Killing Nun in Exorcism|date=19 February 2007|publisher=[[Fox News]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018|quote=Dozens of Corogeanu's supporters packed the courtroom and prayed for the priest, with several bursting into tears when the verdict was announced.}}</ref> The exorcism took place in June 2005.
==Victim== [[File:Vaslui_in_Romania.svg|thumb|200px|[[Vaslui County]] shown on the map of [[Romania]]]] The victim, Maricica Irina Cornici, came from a disadvantaged background, and spent part of her childhood in a [[Romanian orphans|Romanian orphanage]]. In January 2005, the 23-year-old moved to the Tanacu monastery.<ref name="casualty">{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Craig S. |date=July 3, 2005 |title= A Casualty on Romania's Road Back From Atheism |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/03/international/europe/03romania.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |newspaper=New York Times |location= |publisher= |accessdate=October 29, 2013 }}</ref> Tanacu monastery was in [[Vaslui County]], one of the poorest areas of Romania. Cornici was born into a broken family, and, following her father's suicide, she and her brother grew up in an [[orphanage]]. When she was 19, she worked as a [[nanny]] in Germany, and then for a family in Banat.<ref name="casualty"/> A friend of hers from the orphanage became a nun at the Tanacu monastery and she encouraged her to also become a nun.<ref name="casualty"/>
Soon after, she began giggling during March and, by April, her mental state deteriorated and the doctors at the local [[psychiatric hospital]] diagnosed her disease as [[schizophrenia]]. After a two-week treatment, they released her into the care of the monastery.<ref name="casualty"/> Cornici's friends also stated that she never exhibited any signs of mental illness.<ref name="casualty"/> Her brother testified that he was with her when he saw Satan go "into her" and also maintained that she suffered from [[demonic possession]].<ref name="casualty"/>
==Priest== Daniel Petre Corogeanu was the 29-year-old priest of the monastery. A decade before the events, he was a football player in [[Vaslui]], his home town. He began following religious studies at the [[Iași University]] after he could not secure admission in [[Bucharest University]], where he wanted to study sports or law.<ref name="casualty"/> A year later, a businessman from his home town recruited him to help build a monastery in the hills near the city. He was ordained by the local [[bishop]], who expected that he would continue his studies. Nevertheless, he gave up his university education in order to devote himself to running the monastery.<ref name="casualty"/>
In 2003, Father Corogeanu had some disputes with the [[diocese]]. When the bishop came to read him the [[canon law]], he argued that the rules were "19th century innovations" made by the [[Freemasonry]].<ref name="casualty"/> The original community of monks dissolved as they left to become priests and, instead, Corogeanu organized a community of nuns, who were, according to all accounts, "completely devout to him".<ref name="casualty"/>
==The exorcism==
Father Corogeanu thought that it was not just a mental illness, but rather that Cornici was possessed by [[Satan]].<ref name="casualty"/> He would later claim that "you can't take the Devil out of people with pills" and that an exorcism was necessary.<ref name="casualty"/>
In order to restrain her from violent movements including those causing her to hit herself,<ref name="Connolly2005"/><ref name="Bloom2014"/> the nuns bound her hands and feet and locked her in her room as they participated in the liturgy commemorating the [[Ascension of Jesus]]. A few days later, they chained her to a cross with her arms stretched and carried her into the church so that they could anoint her.<ref name="casualty"/> According to Sister Nicoleta Arcalianu, Cornici had been restrained in the same manner that others who were demonically possessed were; Sister Arcalianu stated that had Cornici not been restrained, she "could have either killed herself or killed someone else".<ref name="Scotsman2018"/> With regard to Cornici, Sister Arcalianu stated that "Irina knew that she was possessed by evil spirits because she was begging us to tie her up and help her."<ref name="Scotsman2018"/>
Her wrists and forehead were then anointed with [[Chrism|holy oil]] and she was kept in the church for three days.<ref name="casualty"/> They put a towel into her mouth to stop her from cursing and [[Christian prayer|prayed]] to cast out the [[Devil in Christianity|Devil]] as they wet her lips with [[holy water]].<ref name="casualty"/>
Cornici was then moved to her room and untied. She was, according to Father Corogeanu, "cured". She was later given bread and tea and fainted after eating. The nuns could not arouse her and sensed that her [[pulse]] was weak and as a result they called an [[ambulance]]. While in the ambulance, she was administered six doses of adrenaline.<ref name="Laycock2015"/> By the time she reached the hospital, she was dead.<ref name="casualty"/>
==Aftermath== The police were notified by the doctors at the hospital, who noticed the marks left on her wrists and ankles by the chains. The 2005 [[autopsy]] claimed that she had died of [[dehydration]], [[Fatigue (medical)|exhaustion]] and a lack of oxygen.<ref name="casualty"/>
Father Corogeanu and the four nuns who helped him were charged with murder and depriving a person of liberty.<ref name="casualty"/> Prosecutors sought a [[life sentence]] for Corogeanu, but he was sentenced in 2007 to 14 years in prison, while the nuns (Nicoleta Arcalianu, Adina Cepraga, Elena Otel and Simona Bardanas) were sentenced to between 5 and 8 years.<ref name="FN2007"/><ref name="prison">{{cite news |date=February 20, 2007 |title= Romania: Prison for Priest and Nuns in Exorcism Death |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/20/world/europe/20briefs-exorcism.html?_r=0 |newspaper=New York Times |location= |publisher= |accessdate=October 29, 2013 }}</ref> Many individuals were present in the courtroom to support Father Corogeanu and were distraught at the pronouncement of the verdict.<ref name="FN2007"/> The Court of Appeals reduced his sentence to 7 years.<ref name="procesul">{{cite news |date=January 15, 2008 |title=Procesul în cazul Tanacu, de la instanţa supremă, s-a încheiat |url=http://www.mediafax.ro/justitie/procesul-in-cazul-tanacu-de-la-instanta-suprema-s-a-incheiat-2335848 |newspaper=Mediafax |location= |publisher= |accessdate=October 29, 2013 }}</ref> The nuns also had their punishments reduced to 6 years (one nun) and 5 years (three nuns).<ref>https://romanialibera.ro/actualitate/eveniment/preotul-exorcist-de-la-tanacu-condamnat-la-7-ani-de-inchisoare-video-116709</ref> The priests and the nuns were all found guilty of deprivation of liberty resulting in the victim's death.
Corogeanu was freed on [[parole]] in November 2011 after serving two-thirds of his punishment.<ref name="exorcistul">{{cite news |date=November 30, 2011 |title=Exorcistul de la Tanacu a fost eliberat. Fostul preot Corogeanu a ispasit doua treimi din pedeapsa |url=http://www.hotnews.ro/stiri-ultima_ora-10826915-exorcistul-tanacu-fost-eliberat-fostul-preot-corogeanu-ispasit-doua-treimi-din-pedeapsa.htm |newspaper=Hotnews |location= |publisher= |accessdate=October 29, 2013 }}</ref> The Romanian Orthodox Church closed down the monastery and had Corogeanu defrocked.<ref name="casualty"/>
There is still controversy about the cause of death. Coroner Dan Gheorghiu, who was hired by Corogeanu's lawyer, argues that the cause of death was actually due to an overdose of adrenaline given in the ambulance: "'I was part of the team who handled the exhumation of the nun's body. ...It was concluded that the woman died of an overdose of adrenaline. Don't ask me, I don't know why the judges did not take that into account."<ref name="Bloom2014">{{cite web|title=Romanian priest jailed for killing nun who was CRUCIFIED during botched exorcism|last=Bloom|first=Dan|date=15 July 2014|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018|quote=Coroner Dan Gheorghiu admitted recently that the was some credence to the theory, saying: 'I was part of the team who handled the exhumation of the nun's body. 'It was concluded that the woman died of an overdose of adrenaline. Don't ask me, I don't know why the judges did not take that into account.'}}</ref><ref name="Laycock2015">{{cite book|last=Laycock|first=Joseph P.|title=Spirit Possession around the World: Possession, Communion, and Demon Expulsion across Cultures|date=26 May 2015|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|language=English|isbn=9781610695909|page=333|quote=They untied her and gave her bread and tea. She passed out after eating. The nuns appointed someone to get an ambulance, which arrived around 2:00 p.m. The ambulance doctor gave Cornici six doses of adrenaline and took her to the hospital.}}</ref> Fr. Corogeanu stated that "My biggest mistake was that I called the ambulance when I saw she was not moving. I think she died because the medics who came with the ambulance tried to resuscitate her by giving her too much adrenaline. Had I not called the ambulance, she would have been well now."<ref name="Scotsman2018">{{cite web|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/world/exorcism-priest-is-jailed-for-nun-death-1-682819|title=Exorcism priest is jailed for nun death|publisher=[[The Scotsman]]|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
In Tanacu, many people continue to maintain that Cornici was indeed possessed, rather than mentally ill, and that Corogeanu did his best to help her.<ref name="casualty"/> Veronica Tomulescu stated that "It's not as if they actually killed her. They didn't stab her or shoot her. They took her to the hospital alive."<ref name="casualty"/>
The 2012 movie ''[[Beyond the Hills]]'' directed by [[Cristian Mungiu]] was based on the novels written by [[Tatiana Niculescu Bran]] and inspired by the Tanacu case. ''[[The Crucifixion (film)|The Crucifixion]]'', released in 2017, is also based on Tanacu exorcism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://culturecrypt.com/movie-reviews/the-crucifixion-2017|title=The Crucifixion (2017)|publisher=Culture Crypt|language=English|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Christianity}} *[[Exorcism in Christianity]] *[[Anneliese Michel]] *[[Clara Germana Cele]] *[[Johann Blumhardt]] *[[Michael Taylor (Ossett)]]

'''Tonal''' (To nal) is a concept within the study of [[Mesoamerica]]n religion, myth, folklore and anthropology. It refers to the belief found in many indigenous Mesoamerican cultures that a person upon being born acquires a close spiritual link to an animal, a link that lasts throughout the lives of both creatures. The person shows signs of whatever the animals situation in signs include scratches and bruises if the animals get in fights of illness if the animal is ill.It is in this way similar to the concept of [[Totem]].
== Etymology == The word comes from the [[Nahuatl]] word ''[[tonalli]]'' (to nal li), meaning "day" or "daysign". In the [[Aztec]] belief system the day of a person's birth calculated in the [[Tonalpohualli]] would determine the nature of the person – each day was associated with an animal which could have a strong or weak aspect. The person born on the day of for example "the dog" would then have the strong or weak aspect of the dog. In Nahuatl the word Tonalli was used to refer both to a day and to the animal related to that day. In Mayan belief the concept of an animal companion of a person was referred to as "Way". The modern [[Mixe people]] refer to it as ''Ts'ok'' (Lipp 1991). The [[Jakaltek people|Jakaltek]] Maya people of Concepcion Huista, Guatemala call it ''yixomal ispiẍan nax,'' meaning "soul bearer".
== Studies == The study of tonalism was initiated by noted [[archaeologist]], [[Linguistics|linguist]] and [[ethnologist]] [[Daniel Garrison Brinton]] who published a treatise called [https://web.archive.org/web/20070219214347/http://library.case.edu/ksl/ecoll/books/brinag00/brinag00.html "Nagualism: A Study in Native-American Folklore and History"] which chronicled historical interpretations of the word and those who practiced [[nagualism]] in Mexico in 1894. He identified the different beliefs associated with tonalism in some modern Mexican communities such as the [[Mixe]], the [[Nahua peoples|Nahuas]], the [[Zapotec peoples|Zapotecs]] and [[Mixtec]]s.
== References == *Brinton, Daniel g, 1894, [http://hdl.handle.net/2186/ksl:brinag00/brinag00.pdf "Nagualism: A Study in Native-American Folklore and History"]. *Kaplan, Lucille, 1956, "Tonal and Nagual in Coastal Oaxaca," ''Journal of American Folklore'' 69:363-368 *Lipp, Frank J, 1991, The Mixe of Oaxaca: Religion, ritual and healing, University of Texas Press * Stratmeyer, Dennis & Jean, 1977,"The Jacaltec Nawal and the Soul Bearer in Concepcion Huista", in ''Cognitive Studies of Southern Mesoamerica'', Helen L. Neuenschander and Dean E. Arnold eds., Summer Institute of Linguistics, Museum of Anthropology Publication 3.
